Award.AwardTitle: Graph-Based Control Design for Network Dynamics with Time Delays

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
When complex systems interact with other complex systems, unexpected behavior may result, sometimes with severe consequences. A few examples include stock trading, disease epidemics, vehicle traffic, and opinion propagation in social media. A great deal of progress has been made towards the analysis and control of complex interdependent systems by modeling them as interconnected networks of dynamic nodes, and by making extensive use of the mathematical tools of graph theory. However this framework to date lacks good methods for incorporating the dynamics of the network itself. Yet, in all real systems the time required for communication and decision-making causes delays, and neglecting these can significantly degrade the accuracy of the analytical result. This project will demonstrate new tools to relax the current standard simplifying assumptions -- for example, identical dynamic nodes and uniform delay times -- and allow more realistic models. The project will also show how these new tools may be scaled to address extremely large and complex systems.

Lacking a strong analytical framework, it is common for control engineers to design control systems for complex networked systems while ignoring time delay. Subsequently stable behavior is verified under a highly simplified delay model, with control redesign if the system is sufficiently robust. This project will provide the missing systematic control-design framework, specifically by considering three key ingredients, namely, (i) dynamical systems, (ii) network structure as a parameter, and (iii) the effects of delays on dynamical behavior. Development of such a framework is, however, challenging as network dynamics are large scale, and by the very nature of their design, are impacted by multiple time delays. Moreover a well-established connection between algebraic networks and dynamics affected by time delays does not exist. Recent theoretical results in connecting network graph Laplacian eigenvalues to the eigenvalues associated with the dynamical behavior (~ stability, performance) of a class of network systems with delays show promise in addressing the challenging problem at hand. The intellectual merit of this project lies in expanding such theories to multiple delays, heterogeneous dynamics, and large-scale networks, as well as developing tools to study invariance features between eigenvalues, stability, and performance, and advanced decomposition techniques to simplify the understanding and control design of such networks. The successful completion of this project will lead to the analysis, optimization, and control of large-scale network dynamics affected by time delays, as arising in a broad spectrum of applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many real-world systems surrounding us are examples of network systems. For example, transportation networks comprise of vehicles that interact with each other while circulating on roadways and being subjected to rules and signs. Based on the types of driving strategies (e.g., more/less aggressive) that these vehicles operate can determine the fate of traffic flow, whether or not for example traffic jams may form.

In a more general setting, networks comprise of vehicles/agents/robotic systems that make decisions while interacting with each other. Such interactions in many cases are affected by latency, or time delays. In traffic, delays would arise due to human reaction times, and in coordination of autonomous vehicles, delays can be due to sensing. Regardless of the application domain however delays are often unwanted as they do not allow one to measure/sense information instantaneously or implement decisions without waiting. In the face of delays, the network system may not operate efficiently, optimally, and in some cases the system may fail to work as it would become unstable.

There exists a complex and intimate relationship between the dynamics of interacting agents in a network, the presence of delays, and the patterns, or namely, graphs, describing the information exchange among interacting/non-interacting agents. In the absence of delays, more information exchange among all interacting agents can be beneficial but this is not always the case when delays contaminate information availability or decision making. If this relationship is therefore understood, one could design network systems that operate safely despite the presence of time delays in such networks.

Intellectual merit of this project lies in studying the aforementioned complex relationship in a control theoretic foundation; specifically by developing mathematical tools, algorithms, and computational approaches by which we could explain which graphs/patterns are more suited to prevent instability; how one could design the control logic of agents to avoid instability; and how for large scale networks one could calculate how much of delays the network could tolerate before losing stability.

Broader impacts of this project are seen in training, mentoring, and advising undergraduate students including those from underrepresented and minority groups, a PhD student and a postdoctoral researcher; in dissemination of research results by means of journal and conference publications as well as openly-shared software packages; in outreach activities exposing high-schools students to STEM; in growing international collaborations in research; and in providing research tools that can help study an array of large scale network systems impacted by time delays from transportation and robotic systems to energy grid.

Specifically, the project outcomes include analytical tools to design delay-based controllers in a scalable manner for a class of networks to achieve fast consensus despite measurement noise; the principles of how the presence of delays in a network can help promote self-regulation to prevent instability; analytical approaches into explaining how graph structures in certain networks can promote larger/smaller tolerance to delays; and development of computationally efficient algorithms amenable for parallel computation to calculate the largest delay that a network system can tolerate without losing stability.
